title: A Spectrum of Approximate Probabilistic Bisimulations

sections.introduction:
Probabilistic model checking is widely used for the automatic verification of probabilistic models, like labeled Markov chains (LMC), against properties specified in (temporal) logics like PCTLâˆ—superscriptPCTL\mathrm{PCTL}^{*} . In practice, a big obstacle is the state space explosion problem: the number of states required to model a system can make its verification intractable 7  . To circumvent this issue, a well-established approach is the use of abstractions. For a given LMC â„³â„³\mathcal{M}, an abstraction ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} is a model derived from â„³â„³\mathcal{M} that is (oftentimes) smaller than â„³â„³\mathcal{M} and preserves some properties of interest. Instead of verifying a formula on â„³â„³\mathcal{M}, one does so on ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} and afterwards transfers the result back to the original model   8. A prominent type of abstraction are probabilistic bisimulation quotients. They are constructed w.r.t. probabilistic bisimulations, a class of behavioral equivalences introduced by Larsen and Skou  as an extension of Milnerâ€™s bisimulation  to probabilistic models. A probabilistic bisimulation is an equivalence Rğ‘…R on the state space of an LMC â„³â„³\mathcal{M} that only relates states that behave exactly the same, i.e., that have the same local properties, and transition to Rğ‘…R-equivalence classes with equal probability. The coarsest probabilistic bisimulation âˆ¼similar-to\sim, called (probabilistic) bisimilarity, is the union of all probabilistic bisimulations in â„³â„³\mathcal{M} . The bisimilarity relation can be computed efficiently    and preserves PCTLâˆ—superscriptPCTL\mathrm{PCTL}^{*} state formulas  3. Since verifying PCTLâˆ—superscriptPCTL\mathrm{PCTL}^{*} on bisimulation quotients can significantly speed up the verification process 7, their use is a vital part of probabilistic model checkers such as, e.g., Storm . Other notions of behavioral equivalence are weakÂ and branching probabilistic bisimulations      , which were introduced with the intention to abstract from sequences of internal actions or stutter steps a model can perform. Intuitively, these notions can abstract from the possibility of a state to, for some time, only visit equally labeled states (weak) or stay in its own equivalence class (branching) .
It is well-known that weak and branching probabilistic bisimilarity, denoted â‰ˆwsuperscriptğ‘¤\approx^{w} and â‰ˆbsuperscriptğ‘\approx^{b}, respectively, coincide for LMCs , and that they characterize satisfaction equivalence for a variant of PCTLâˆ—superscriptPCTL\mathrm{PCTL}^{*} . A problem with all of the above notions lies, however, in their lack of robustness against errors in the transition probabilities. The requirement of related states to have exactly the same transition probabilities to equivalence classes implies that even an infinitesimally small perturbation of any of these probabilities can cause two bisimilar states to become non-bisimilar, resulting in larger quotients   .
This disadvantage was first observed in , where the use of approximate notions of bisimulation is suggested for its mitigation. The literature proposes various types of approximate bisimilarity, the most well-known and well-studied one being Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimilarity (âˆ¼Îµsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€\sim_{\varepsilon}) . Other notions include approximate probabilistic bisimilarity with precision Îµğœ€\varepsilon (â‰¡Îµsubscriptğœ€\equiv_{\varepsilon}), or Îµğœ€\varepsilon-APB for short   , up-to-(n,Îµ)ğ‘›ğœ€(n,\varepsilon)-bisimilarity (âˆ¼Îµnsuperscriptsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€ğ‘›\sim_{\varepsilon}^{n})  3, or Îµğœ€\varepsilon-lumpability of a given LMC 7 9 8. Here, we propose definitions for approximate versions of weak (â‰ˆÎµwsuperscriptsubscriptğœ€ğ‘¤\approx_{\varepsilon}^{w}) and branching probabilistic bisimilarity (â‰ˆÎµbsuperscriptsubscriptğœ€ğ‘\approx_{\varepsilon}^{b}). Similar notions have, to the best of our knowledge, only been discussed sporadically in the context of noninterference under the term â€œweak bisimulation with precision Îµğœ€\varepsilonâ€     6 . Moreover, we introduce Îµğœ€\varepsilon-perturbed bisimilarity (â‰ƒÎµsubscriptsimilar-to-or-equalsğœ€\simeq_{\varepsilon}) which relates two LMCs if they can be made bisimilar by small perturbations of their transition probabilities. Implicitly, this relation arises in the work 8 on a type of abstraction called Îµğœ€\varepsilon-quotients. With our definition, two LMCs are Îµğœ€\varepsilon-perturbed bisimilar iff they have bisimilar Îµğœ€\varepsilon-quotients. All of the approximate notions have in common that they allow a small tolerance, say Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, in the transition probabilities of related states, but differ in the specifics of where and how this tolerance is put to use. Broadly speaking, we can distinguish two groups of relations: while âˆ¼Îµsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€\sim_{\varepsilon}, â‰¡Îµ,âˆ¼Îµnsubscriptğœ€superscriptsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€ğ‘›\equiv_{\varepsilon},\sim_{\varepsilon}^{n} and â‰ˆÎµwsuperscriptsubscriptğœ€ğ‘¤\approx_{\varepsilon}^{w} are additive in their tolerances and are closer to classic process relations, the notions underlying âˆ¼Îµâˆ—superscriptsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€\sim_{\varepsilon}^{*} and â‰¡Îµâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğœ€\equiv_{\varepsilon}^{*}, denoting transitiveÂ Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimilarity and transitive Îµğœ€\varepsilon-APB, respectively, as well as â‰ƒÎµsubscriptsimilar-to-or-equalsğœ€\simeq_{\varepsilon} and â‰ˆÎµbsuperscriptsubscriptğœ€ğ‘\approx_{\varepsilon}^{b} are better suited for the construction of abstractions since they are required to be equivalences. Collapsing the equivalence classes of such a relation into single states yields quotient models, which in some cases are such that formulas given in specific (fragments of) logics are (approximately) preserved between the original LMC and its quotient. However, as we will see later, requiring transitivity can cause some unnatural behavior like the possibility to distinguish probabilistically bisimilar LMCs and a lack of additivity. Furthermore, the induced bisimilarity relations, which are again defined as the union of all corresponding relations in the model â„³â„³\mathcal{M} (e.g., â‰ˆÎµbsuperscriptsubscriptğœ€ğ‘\approx_{\varepsilon}^{b} is the union of all branching Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimulations in â„³â„³\mathcal{M}) might themselves not be of the respective type anymore (e.g., â‰ˆÎµbsuperscriptsubscriptğœ€ğ‘\approx_{\varepsilon}^{b} is not necessarily a branching Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimulation). This contrasts the non-transitive case, where the induced bisimilarity relations are always of the respective type. We summarize the relations we consider, together with some of their properties, in TableÂ 1. Main Contributions.Â The main contributions are as follows: Starting with the classic notion of Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimilarity, we show tightness of a bound from 2 on the absolute difference of unbounded reachability probabilities in Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimilar states (ExampleÂ 3.13). We introduce Îµğœ€\varepsilon-perturbed bisimilarity (â‰ƒÎµsubscriptsimilar-to-or-equalsğœ€\simeq_{\varepsilon}), a notion that relates two LMCs if they have bisimilar Îµğœ€\varepsilon-quotients Ã¡ la 8, i.e., if they can be made probabilistically bisimilar by small perturbations of their transition probabilities. We show that â‰ƒÎµsubscriptsimilar-to-or-equalsğœ€\simeq_{\varepsilon} is strictly finer than (transitive) Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimilarity âˆ¼Îµ(âˆ—)superscriptsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€\sim_{\varepsilon}^{(*)} (LemmasÂ 4.6 andÂ 4.7) and that deciding both â‰ƒÎµsubscriptsimilar-to-or-equalsğœ€\simeq_{\varepsilon} and âˆ¼Îµâˆ—superscriptsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€\sim_{\varepsilon}^{*} is NP-complete (TheoremÂ 4.13). Furthermore, we characterize â‰ƒÎµsubscriptsimilar-to-or-equalsğœ€\simeq_{\varepsilon} in terms of transitive Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimulations satisfying a centroid property (TheoremÂ 4.11) and discuss some anomalies of â‰ƒÎµsubscriptsimilar-to-or-equalsğœ€\simeq_{\varepsilon}: the relation is not always an Îµğœ€\varepsilon-perturbed bisimulation itself, it is not additive in Îµğœ€\varepsilon and it can distinguish bisimilar LMCs (PropositionÂ 4.4). We define approximate versions of weak (â‰ˆÎµwsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğœ€\approx^{w}_{\varepsilon}) and branching probabilistic bisimilarity (â‰ˆÎµbsuperscriptsubscriptğœ€ğ‘\approx_{\varepsilon}^{b}). Our definitions can be evaluated locally and coincide with the exact notions â‰ˆbsuperscriptğ‘\approx^{b} and â‰ˆwsuperscriptğ‘¤\approx^{w}, respectively, if Îµ=0ğœ€0\varepsilon=0. We discuss how â‰ˆÎµwsuperscriptsubscriptğœ€ğ‘¤\approx_{\varepsilon}^{w} and â‰ˆÎµbsuperscriptsubscriptğœ€ğ‘\approx_{\varepsilon}^{b} are related to one another, as well as to Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimilarity (PropositionsÂ 5.4 andÂ 5.6). Moreover, we extend the bounds for reachability probabilities of TheoremÂ 3.11 to states related by â‰ˆÎµwsuperscriptsubscriptğœ€ğ‘¤\approx_{\varepsilon}^{w} and â‰ˆÎµbsuperscriptsubscriptğœ€ğ‘\approx_{\varepsilon}^{b} (CorollariesÂ 5.11 andÂ 5.12), and prove that deciding â‰ˆÎµbsuperscriptsubscriptğœ€ğ‘\approx_{\varepsilon}^{b} is NP-complete (TheoremÂ 5.14). Together with various known results from the literature and some easy observations, our results complete the relation between several notions of approximate probabilistic bisimulation, as summarized in FigureÂ 1. Structure. SectionÂ 2 presents preliminaries. SectionÂ 3 considers Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimulations, Îµğœ€\varepsilon-APBs and up-to-(n,Îµ)ğ‘›ğœ€(n,\varepsilon)-bisimulations. SectionÂ 4 introduces and analyzes Îµğœ€\varepsilon-perturbed bisimulations. SectionÂ 5 introduces weak and branching Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimulations and establishes how they relate to Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimulations. SectionÂ 6 summarizes our results and points out future work.
